Advanced JavaScript - this

16 Feb 2017

The this keyword in JavaScript seems to be one of the most confusing mechanisms in the entire language. It is often compared to self in Ruby, which is a completely false comparison. In this blog post I am going to break down why that is, and how developers can effectively leverage the use of this instead of sit and wonder why things are breaking.

At its core, this is a run-time binding. In other words, it is a binding that is made when a function is invoked, and what it references is determined by the callsite of the function. The callsite is the place in code where a function gets executed. Every function, while executing, has a reference to its current execution context, called this.

There are 4 main rules to follow when we think about this.

  1. Was the function called with new? If yes, this is that object.
  2. Was the function called with call() or apply()? If yes, use the passed in this argument.
  3. Was the function called with a containing object? If yes, use that object.
  4. Default: fall back to global context, unless in strict mode.

Thatâ€™s it! These rules are in order of precedence, so the new keyword will always overwrite a containing object. The big take away here if you want to determine this is to focus on the callsite, then ask yourself those 4 rules.

If you like what you read you can check out my previous posts listed in my archive. Or you can check out my github here.
